item.title: Human-Computer Interaction
item.description:
(Work in progress) Human-Computer Interaction

Learning Goal

  • common principles in HCI
  • design life cycle, and importance of iteration
  • current applications of HCI

Learning Outcome

  • design effective interactions between humans and computers
  • design: applying known principles to a new problem and interative processing of needfinding, prototyping and evaluaiton
  • effectiveness: usability/research/change
  • design interactions, not interfaces (shift on emphasis)

Introduction to HCI

  • the goal is to create a scenario where user spends as much time as possible to accomplish the task, while the interface kind of vanishes during that interaction
  • a video game, as an example gives the user an experience of being in the game, not tinkering with the controller
  • ubiquity
  • we might be experts at interacting with computers, but that does not make us experts at designing interactions between other humans and computers
  • HCI is complex and large
  • HCI is a subset of Human Factors Engineering (Industrial Design, HCI, Product Design)
  • UI Design and UX Design and Interaction Design are a subset of HCI
  • Many principle of HCI come from Human Factors Engineering applied to computers
  • Tha gap between HCI and Interaction Design is shrinking (as computers become ubiquitious)
  • HCI is about understanding the interaction between users and computers, and UX design is about dictating the interaction between users and computer. The relationship is howerver, deeply symbiotic.
  • Human Factors Engineering is a merger of Engineering and Psychology
  • Psychology and HCI are also deeply symbiotic
  • HCI is about research (needfinding, prototyping, evaluation) and design (distributed congnition, mental models, universal design)
  • HCI at its core: Research informs Design and Design informs Research

Exploring HCI

  • Technologies
    • Virtual Reality
    • Augmented Reality
    • UbiComp and Wearables
    • Robotics
    • Mobile
  • Ideas
    • Context-Sensitive Computing
    • Gesture-Based Interaction
    • Pen-and Touch-Based Interaction
    • Information Visualization
    • CSCW (Computer Supported Cooperative Work) Interaction (Distributed Team, Distributed Work, Temporal and Geographical dimension): Example: Slack, Online course, etc.
    • Social Computing
  • Domain
    • Special Needs (example: communicating data using sound for visually impaired people)
    • Education (you might not always want to make something super easy)
    • Healthcare (fitbit, virtual reality)
    • Security (for security to be useful, it has to be usable). Captcha has become easy now with a checkbox
    • Games (topics of HCI are super salient here)
